description: From Old French tumultuous (modern French tumultueux), from Latin tumultuōsus (“restless, turbulent”), from tumultus (“disturbance, uproar, violent commotion, tumult; agitation, disturbance, excitement”) + -ōsus (suffix meaning ‘full of, prone to’ forming adjectives from nouns).

adjectives.description: tumultuous (comparative more tumultuous, superlative most tumultuous)

entries.meaning: Characterized by loud, confused noise. [from mid 16th c.]
examples: Synonyms: noisy, uproarious; see also Thesaurus:noisy

entries.meaning: Causing or characterized by tumult; chaotic, disorderly, turbulent. [from mid 16th c.]
examples: Synonyms: riotous, tempestuous, tumultuary; see also Thesaurus:disorderly
